name: Swiss Cheese Model
description: A model used to illustrate how layers of defense can prevent accidents.

layers.name: Organizational Culture
layers.description: The shared values, beliefs, and practices within an organization that influence how safety is prioritized.

holes.name: Lack of Safety Reporting
holes.description: Insufficient mechanisms for reporting safety issues can lead to unaddressed risks.

sub-classes.name: Fear of Repercussions
sub-classes.description: Employees may fear punishment for reporting safety issues, leading to underreporting.

sub-classes.name: Inadequate Feedback Mechanisms
sub-classes.description: Lack of feedback on reported issues can discourage future reporting.

holes.name: Poor Communication
holes.description: Ineffective communication can result in misunderstandings and overlooked safety protocols.

sub-classes.name: Information Silos
sub-classes.description: Departments may not share critical safety information, leading to gaps in knowledge.

sub-classes.name: Ambiguous Safety Messages
sub-classes.description: Unclear safety instructions can lead to confusion and non-compliance.

layers.name: Training and Competence
layers.description: Ensuring that all personnel are adequately trained and competent in their roles to prevent errors.

holes.name: Inadequate Training
holes.description: Insufficient training can lead to mistakes and unsafe practices.

sub-classes.name: Lack of Initial Training
sub-classes.description: New employees may not receive comprehensive training before starting work.

sub-classes.name: Insufficient Refresher Courses
sub-classes.description: Ongoing training may be neglected, leading to skill atrophy.

holes.name: Skill Degradation
holes.description: Over time, skills may degrade if not regularly practiced or updated.

sub-classes.name: Lack of Practice
sub-classes.description: Employees may not have opportunities to practice critical skills regularly.

sub-classes.name: Failure to Update Skills
sub-classes.description: New technologies or procedures may not be integrated into training programs.

layers.name: Operational Procedures
layers.description: Standardized procedures that guide operations and help prevent mistakes.

holes.name: Non-compliance with Procedures
holes.description: Failure to follow established procedures can lead to accidents.

sub-classes.name: Lack of Adherence
sub-classes.description: Employees may skip steps in procedures due to time pressure or complacency.

sub-classes.name: Procedural Complexity
sub-classes.description: Overly complex procedures can lead to confusion and non-compliance.

holes.name: Outdated Procedures
holes.description: Procedures that are not regularly updated may not reflect current best practices.

sub-classes.name: Failure to Review
sub-classes.description: Procedures may not be reviewed regularly, leading to outdated practices.

sub-classes.name: Lack of Stakeholder Input
sub-classes.description: Procedures may be developed without input from those who use them, leading to impractical guidelines.
